bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 18, 1901

div1.p: Reed discusses the army reorganization bill. He has finished his paper and remarks that the last experimental yellow fever cases are recovering.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 18, 1901
div1.opener:
Friday night,
Columbia Barracks,
January 18, 1901.
My precious wifie dear:
div1.p:
What was that
you were telling me about your fine
weather in the U. S. in your last letter
of the 12th? Well, surely you have
had a touch of winter now, for yes-
terday, a norther, accompanied by a drench-
ing rain, set in, and oh! ye little
fishes! how it did blow last night!
I thought certainly that the roof would
come off! To-night, as I write, I am
sitting in my room with my over-
coat on, while the termometer stands
at 64°! Now doesn't that sound
perfectly absurd, that a mortal
should need an overcoat at 64°?
Nevertheless, it is true on this
Pearl of the Antilles- The wind
blows so constantly that it cools
one off until his marrow-bones
fairly chill! This morning, when I
want in to take my shower-bath, the
water was so cold that it made
me fairly yell- Tomorrow, if the sun
comes out, it will be so warm
that we will soon forget all about
our blizzard! In the meanwhile,
you must have been having it
dreadfully cold in the States. Do pray
keep your toes warm this kind
of weather- Don't bother any more
about my coming by way of Tam-
pa- The other route is alright &
I will get through in very good
shape I am sure- You must
know that I am a better sailor
than I used to be- What a fashionable
lady, not to be rising until 10 o'clock
in the morning- Great Scott! I
get up at 7 a.m. every day! I am
certain that you must have en-
joyed Maud Adams so much- How
I would like to have seen her with
you and the fat girls- I refer, of course,
to Miss Lucy and Miss Anna-polis-
Did you give our sweet scholar, mother
dear, $1.00 for her dear father? Don't for-
get that, for her report richly de-
serves it- We hear that the Army
Reorganization bill has passed the
senate! I only get 4 files, but that
helps out about one year in my
promotion, so I am not going to
growl any- I would have liked 14 files
better- But we must be satisfied
with what we get. It's too bad
that you are having La Grippe
again in Washington- I wonder if
it is really true- I do so hope that
you and precious joy will escape-
Why shouldn't our good friend, Dr
Hoff be made Surgeon General? He
would make an excellent one-
He came to Washington to take Dr
Bushnell's place, and since the latter
had to go, on account of his health,
a better selection could not have
been made- I hear that Dr Bache
is not well at all- I am so sorry
to hear it- He is such a nice, com-
panionable man- Well, I have finished
writing the paper which we will pre-
sent here in February -- and am glad
to get it off my hands -- our last cases
are now Convalescent- Am going down
to see Gen. Wood on business in the
morning -- and to give him a short abstract
of our results for his annual Report,
Good-night, you sweet joys! Take
good care of your darling selves
during this cold weather- Boo! Boo! Love
& kisses & kisses & love for my precious,
precious girls-
